poem:
I press my brakes against the heartbeat of the city—  
metal sighs under neon, the hiss of tires on wet asphalt.  
I reckon the map in my wheels, tracing every crooked alley,  
a serpent uncoiling at every intersection.

I barrel past a flock of honking geese,  
their stubborn parade across the pavement ignored.  
Feathers ruffle in mild indignation,  
but the city’s pulse demands I move on.

Around me, walls bleed color—  
sprays of cobalt and firebrand orange,  
letters curling into names no one remembers.  
I linger in their shadows, engines idling,  
as if to drink in each stroke of graffiti before I go.

Headlights carve through dusk,  
spilling light over broken sidewalks where footsteps echo.  
I collect stray scents—the sharp tang of rain on concrete,  
the fried onions from a street-cart kebab,  
and the faint sweetness of wisteria climbing a brick stoop.

Passengers sway in my belly,  
lost in their own reveries:  
a student cradling a sketchbook,  
an old woman fingers ready for prayer,  
a young man tracing guitar riffs on his phone.

The city hums beneath my chassis,  
an unpredictable melody of horns and laughter.  
I am both guide and wanderer,  
bearing witness to spilled secrets in graffiti tags,  
the quiet indignation of geese,  
the restless stir of souls in transit.

I do not promise smooth journeys—  
curling curves might jar your spine,  
unexpected detours might redraw your skyline.  
But I carry you through the city’s rough poetry,  
through its sudden halts and silent bursts of color,  
until we spill apart beneath streetlights  
and each of us steps into our own unfolding story.
